10.1016/j.jechem.2018.06.011 Fig. 1 (a) Schematic diagram depicts the synthesis process of alluaudite based Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF cathode for SIB [86]. (b) Schematic diagram depicts the synthesis process of V2O5-nano-belt-MWCNTs cathode for SIB [90]. (c) Schematic diagram for the synthesis of polydopamine-FWCNTs depicts the self-polymerization of dopamine in weak alkaline electrolyte and continuous deposition process of polydopamine on FWCNTs and (d) digital image depicts the flexibility of polydopamine-FWCNTs composite cathode [87]. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) The binder-free flexible rGO-polyimide cathode was obtained by mechanical pressing of the as-prepared material from ∼2 mm (top) to ∼30 µm thin film (bottom) [38]. (b) The schematic diagram depicts the Na7V4(P2O7)4(PO4)-C-graphene cathode with bicontinuous ion/electron transport pathways, where the vertical/parallel views of a layer and enlarged single nanorod are also shown [93]. (c) Schematic diagram of Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2-rGO cathode [94]. (d) Prussian blue @ GO@Ni - cotton textile cathode powers LED at bent state (inset: at unbent state) [88]. (e) Digital image depicts the flexibility of Na2FeP2O7 CC cathode [89]. (f) and (g) SEM micrographs of FeFe(CN)6 CC cathode at low and high magnification [92]. (h) Schematic diagram depicts the synthesis of H2V3O8 nanowire membrane cathode [91]. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) and (b) SEM images of P-doped carbon cloth at different magnifications [110]. (c) Schematic diagram of the synthesis of Li4Ti5O12 C-rGO anode [118]. (d) Schematic diagram depicts the pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N in Sn-nano-dot-N–C NF [115], and (e) discharge/charge profile of Sn-nano-dot-N–C NF at 200 mA g‒1 in the voltage window of 0.02‒2 V (inset: HRTEM images of reaction products after 1st discharge and charge process) [115]. (f) Unit cell of crystalline Na15Sn4 with the space group I-43d, where the yellow balls indicate Na ions and the red balls indicate Sn [125]. (g) Schematic diagram of the synthesis of CuCo2O4 nano-dot@NC NF anode for SIB [126]. (h) SEM micrograph of CuO nanorod array on Cu foil [133]. (i) Schematic illustration of Na-ions storage mechanism in polypyrrole film [127]. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) Digital images depict the flexibility of hybrid solid electrolyte for NaFePO4//hard carbon SIB, and (b) Schematic model illustrate the mechanism of Na-ion conducting paths in hybrid solid electrolyte [151]. (c) At bent state, Na3V2(PO4)3//NC sheet full cell powers flexible/wearable LED screen [148]. (d) Schematic illustration depicts the fabrication of flexible Na3V2(PO4)3/rGO//Sb/rGO full cell [152]. (e‒g) Flexible PDMS/rGO sponge/VOPO4//PDMS/rGO sponge/hard carbon full cell [150]. (e) Schematic diagram depicts the fabrication of flexible full cell, (f) digital images of the full cell powers LED at normal state (top) and at ∼50% stretched state (bottom), and (g) charge-discharge curves of the full cell after 50 and 100 times stretched at 10 mA g‒1 [150]. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Specific capacity of the foldable Li–S battery after 1, 10, and 100 folding/unfolding cycles at 837.5 mA g‒1, where the Li and S are patterned into the CNT current collector [169]. (b) The cycling stability of Li–S battery (with C@S-CNTs as cathode) for 50 cycles at bent state at current density of 1 C [174]. (c) Preparation of S8 loaded MOFs-CNTs composite films, and the scale bars in the SEM images represent 1 µm, where MOFs, CNT, MHNs, indicate the metal-organic frameworks, carbon nanotubes, and metal hydroxide nano-strands, respectively [160]. (d) Li–S battery with S-MOFs-CNTs as cathode powers LED at various bending angles [160]. (e) The cycling stability of Li–S battery (with Li2S6 CNTs as cathode) for 80 cycles at unfolded/folded state at 167.5 mA g‒1 [173]. (f) The cycling stability of Li–S battery (with bucky paper-S-bucky paper as cathode) for 100 cycles at folded state and it powers LED at bent state (inset) [167]. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) The cycling stability of Li–S battery (with porous C-S as cathode) for 10 cycles at 837.5 mA g‒1 followed by 10 cycles at 1675 mA g‒1 at bent state [162]. (b) Characterization of Li2S-NCNF cathode after cycling stability test for 200 cycles at 1166 mA g‒1 [165]: (b1) optical image, (b2 and b3) FESEM images of cathode after 200 cycles, and (b4) TEM image of cathode after 200 cycles and its corresponding elemental mapping disclosing the homogeneous elemental distribution of N, S, and C. (c) Proposed configuration for Li2S-graphene cathode, where Li2S compound intercalated into two graphene molecule interlayers [161]. (d) Scheme (d1‒d3) depicts the preparation of rGO-S cathode on stainless steel fiber by capillary action, and (d4 and d5) schematic diagram shows the wire-shaped-flexible-Li–S battery [163]. Department of Physics and Materials Science City University of Hong Kong Tat Chee Avenue Kowloon Hong Kong China Flexible energy storage devices are essential for emerging flexible electronics. The existing state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries are slowly reaching their limitation in terms of cost and energy density. Hence, flexible Na-ion batteries (SIBs) with abundance Na resources and Li–S batteries with high energy density become the alternative for the Li-ion batteries in future. This review summarizes the recent advances in the development of flexible electrode materials for SIBs with metallic matrix and carbonaceous matrix such as carbon nano-tubes, carbon nano-fiber, graphene, carbon cloth, carbon fiber cloth, and cotton textiles. Then, the potential prototype flexible full SIBs are discussed. Further, the recent progress in the development of flexible electrode materials for Li–S batteries based on carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, and cotton textiles is reviewed. Moreover, the design strategies of suitable interlayer, separator, electrolyte, and electrodes to prevent the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in flexible Li–S batteries are provided. Finally some prospective investigation trends towards future research of flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries are also proposed and discussed. The scientific and engineering knowledge gained on flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries provides conceivable development for practical application in near future. Graphical abstract The recent advances in the development of flexible electrode materials with metallic matrix and carbonaceous matrix for flexible Na-ion batteries (with abundance Na resources) and Li–S batteries (with high energy density) have been reviewed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Na-ion batteries Lithium–sulfur batteries Flexible Free-standing High performance energy storage Long cycle life 1 Introduction 1.1 Need for Na-ion and Li–S batteries The ever increasing energy demand leads to depletion of fossil fuels and increase in environmental pollution, which demands for the production of sustainable clean energies from renewable energy sources such as solar, wave, wind [1–7]. In order to integrate these sustainable energies into the electrical grid, a large scale energy storage system is important to peak shift operation [8], where the electrochemical secondary batteries have been considered as a promising way among the various electrical storage technologies due to their simple maintenance, flexibility, and high energy conversion efficiency [8,9]. Among secondary batteries, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) [7,10] have been substantially used in portable electronics and electric vehicles and their uses in recent years are tremendously increasing. Moreover, the global consumption cost of LIBs in 2009 for portable electronics was ∼7 billion US$ [11] while the worldwide production of LIBs in 2016 was 28 GWh [12], and those clearly indicate the substantially much high commercial usage of LIBs but the Li source in earth's crust is limited to ∼20 ppm [13–15], which could significantly affect the production of LIBs especially in term of cost in the future. In this respect, Na-ion batteries (SIBs) and Li–S batteries can be the promising alternative for the state-of-the-art LIBs. On one hand, SIBs are considered much attention [2,15] due to the abundance resources of Na (> 2%) in earth's crust [13] and its abundance in ocean is infinite. On the other hand, Li–S batteries with S as abundance, non-toxic source have been considered much attractive because it affords high energy density of 2600 Wh kg‒1, which is endowed by multi-electron chemistry, and the energy density of Li–S batteries is ∼5 times higher than that of LIBs at a comparably lower cost [16,17]. 1.2 SIBs batteries Reversible SIB is comprised of cathode, anode, electrolyte, and separator. Upon discharging the SIB, Na-ions deintercalate from the lattice sites of anode (oxidation), while Na-ions intercalate into the lattice sites of cathode (reduction), and electrons moves from the anode to cathode in the external circuit. However, poor cycling stability and low capacity of SIBs limit its application due to the poor electrical conductivity, slower kinetic diffusion, and large volume expansion during the Na-ion intercalation/deintercalation process. Hence, tailoring suitable cathodes, anodes, and electrolytes are essential to achieve high performance SIBs. Table 1 shows the theoretical capacity and voltage of cathode and anode materials for SIBs [18–32], while Table 2 depicts the working potential range, capacity, and cycling stability of recently reported different kinds of cathode and anode materials for SIBs. Various high performance cathode materials for SIBs (Table 2) such as layered oxide materials [33,34], polyanionic compounds [35,36], metal-hexacyanometalates [37], and organic compounds [38] have been developed. Pomegranate-like Na3V2(PO4)3 C composite cathode [36] exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining ∼57 mAh g‒1 (74.7%) of discharge capacity at 2340 mA g‒1 after 10,000 cycles. Several high performance anode materials for SIBs (Table 2) such as carbonaceous materials [39,40], sulfides [41], oxides [42], alloys [43], and polymers [44] have been developed. 2D conjugated aromatic polymer [44] is prepared by solid state polymerization (based on C–C coupling reactions), which exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining ∼79 mAh g‒1 (70%) of discharge capacity at 5000 mA g‒1 after 7700 cycles. Different electrolytes such as liquid, gel state, and solid state have been developed [45]. Solid-state electrolytes includes glass-ceramic and solid-polymer composite; Liquid electrolyte includes water, ionic liquid, organic carbonate ester, and ether. A carbonaceous anode [46] in ether-based diglyme electrolyte exhibits high initial Coulombic efficiency, which could be due to the formation of ion conducting, uniform, and thin solid electrolyte interphase layer in ether-based electrolyte. Recently, promising SIBs using Na3V2(PO4)3 cathodes, hard carbon anodes, and other electrode materials have been developed [2,19,47–49], but those have been limited due to the inferior cycling stability, less energy and power density. The research and technological development on SIBs are still in developing stage to reach practical application but still some prototypes of SIBs are also commercialized by Aquion Energy (USA), Sharp laboratory (US), Faradion (UK), and CNRS/RS2E (France) [2]. 1.3 Li–S batteries Li–S battery is composed of sulfur cathode, Li metal anode, electrolyte, and separator, and the following reversible reactions occur upon charge and discharge process [50]: Charge process: at sulfur cathode: 8 Li2S → S8 + 16 Li+ + 16 e−; at Li anode: Li+ + e−→ Li. Discharge process: at sulfur cathode: S8 + 16 Li+ + 16 e−→ 8 Li2S; at Li anode: Li → Li+ + e−. Upon discharging the Li–S battery, oxidation occurs at the anode, where metallic Li converts into Li-ions, while long chain polysulfides (Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8)) are formed at the sulfur cathode by various reaction stages [51,52] (S8 + 2 e−→ S8 2−; 3 S8 2 − + 2 e−→ 4 S6 2−; 2 S6 2 − + 2 e−→ 3 S4 2−; S4 2 − + 4 Li+ + 2 e−→ 2 Li2S2; Li2S2 + 2 Li+ + 2 e−→ 2 Li2S), which dissolve in the electrolyte and then insoluble Li2S2 and/or Li2S are precipitated, while opposite reactions occur during the charge process [17,53–56]. However, Li–S batteries exhibit poor cycling stability and electrochemical performance due to the intrinsic electronic conductivity of sulfur active materials and their large volume change upon cycling, shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides intermediates between Li anode and sulfur cathode, dissolution of lithium polysulfides, and passivation of Li anode [50,57]. In this respect, tailoring the cathode materials with high utilization of sulfur and long life span can obviate the shuttling effect of the polysulfides between cathode and anode, and that improves the efficiency of the Li–S batteries. Several attempts have been performed to improve the performance of Li–S batteries [56,58–71]. Various high performance Li–S batteries such as TiO2/S//Li [62], FeS2//Li [63], Ti6O11/S//Li [62], Ti4O7/S//Li [62], Ti4O7/S//Li [64], δ-MnO2/S//Li [65], and Co9S8/S//Li [66] have been developed. Ti4O7/S//Li [64] Li–S battery exhibits high cycling stability by retaining 595 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at much high current density of 3350 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles. Currently, promising Li–S batteries have been developed but those are limited because of their poor cycling stability and electrochemical performance due to the intrinsic electronic conductivity of sulfur active materials and their large volume change upon cycling, shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides intermediates between Li anode and sulfur cathode, dissolution of lithium polysulfides, and passivation of Li anode. The research and technological development on Li–S batteries are still in developing stage to reach practical application. 1.4 Flexible batteries and objective of this review Developing flexible electronic devices can afford high portability in wide range of environment. However, the material should possess additional functionalities in some particular applications. If the material is considered for implantable application, then it could be biocompatible [72,73], flexible [74], and biodegradable [75,76]; If the material is considered for transparent devices, then it could be transparent [77,78]. Several flexible prototype devices such as solar cells [79], rolled-up displays [78], artificial skins [80], artificial synapse [81], and artificial electric organ [82] have been demonstrated. Therefore, developments of several flexible and thin electrode materials for batteries are necessary to achieve the thin and flexible requirements of devices. Flexible electrode materials are generally comprised of active materials, which are anchored on flexible conductive matrix [83]. Hence, they possess several advantages such as they can be lightweight, thin, and flexible, and they can also obviate the usage of binders, additives, and current collector, but those could also significantly influence the energy storage performance. In particular, designing suitable flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries can afford significant merits in the development of flexible electronic devices, where SIBs with abundance Na resources and Li–S batteries with high energy density can be the possible alternative for the state of the art Li-ion batteries in future. Several reviews on SIBs [2,15,19,45] and Li–S batteries [56,59–61] have been reported whereas reviews on flexible electrodes for SIBs [84] and Li–S batteries [85] are limited. In this respect, this paper reviews the recent progress of flexible electrode materials with metallic matrix and carbon matrix such as carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, cotton textiles, carbon cloth, and carbon fiber cloth for the development of flexible SIBs. Later, this paper identifies the potential prototype flexible full SIBs. Then, this paper discusses the recent advances of flexible electrode materials with carbon matrix such as carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, and cotton textiles for the development of flexible Li–S batteries. In addition, the design strategies of suitable interlayer, separator, electrolyte, and electrodes to prevent the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides for the development of flexible Li–S batteries have been provided. Finally some prospective investigation trends towards future research of flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries have also proposed and discussed. 2 Flexible SIBs 2.1 Flexible cathode materials for SIBs 2.1.1 Flexible cathode materials with carbon matrix for SIBs Hybridizing the potential cathode materials with carbonaceous materials such as carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, cotton textiles, carbon cloth, and carbon fiber cloth is the useful strategy for the fabrication of flexible cathode materials for SIBs, which can also enhance high electronic/ionic conductivity and that enhance the electrochemical properties. Table 3 shows the working potential range, capacity, and cycling stability of recently reported several types of flexible cathode materials for SIBs [38,86–97]. Carbon-nano-fibers matrix can provide high flexibility while their electrospinning synthesis process is a versatile technology. Hence integrating active materials with carbon-nano-fibers can not only afford flexibility but also improve electronic conductivity and that enhances its electrochemical performance. Yu et al. [86] have demonstrated Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF (NF: nano-fiber) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the alluaudite-type Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF as depicted in the schematic diagram of Fig. 1 (a) (More details of the preparation process were given in Table S1(a)). They observed that the Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF composite comprised of sulfate nanoparticles of 5‒10 nm in size, which are enwrapped by graphitic-like porous carbon nanofibers of 50‒100 nm in diameter, where the flexible, porous, and conductive framework enhances the ion/electron transport and cycling stability. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits capacity of ∼53 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 3880 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼85 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 97 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from ∼4.3‒2.0 V. Hollow γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) with cation vacancies can be used as a promising earth-abundant cathode material for the fast intercalation of Na+ at high voltage. Koo et al. [95] have demonstrated hollow γ-Fe2O3 CNTs (NTs: nano-tubes) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the hollow γ-Fe2O3 CNTs composite as follows: Hollow γ-Fe2O3 NPs was obtained by annealing of 5.8 nm of Fe core/2.8 nm of Fe2O3 shell, while the composite cathode was prepared in the presence of CNTs, where the encapsulation of hollow nanoparticles between the layers of CNTs could improve the stability of the cathode. They observed that the γ-Fe2O3 CNTs cathode decomposes the NaClO4/propylene carbonate (PC) electrolyte after cycling at low current density because of the CNTs catalysis side reactions whereas the cathode exhibits high electrochemical performance in NaPF6/PC electrolyte after cycling at low/high current density. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits capacity of ∼50 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 3000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 63 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 3000 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒1.1 V. Preparing promising nanostructured cathode materials for SIBs using simple and green synthetic route are important. Rui et al. [90] have demonstrated V2O5-nano-belt-MWCNTs (MWCNTs: multi-walled carbon nano-tubes) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the V2O5-nano-belt-MWCNTs using simple, green, and cost-effective procedure (Fig. 1b; Table S1(b)). They observed that the V2O5 nanobelt was orthogonal V2O5 with [010] orientation and it was ∼5 nm in thickness and 5‒50 nm in width, which facilitates electrolyte interaction. They found that the growth of V2O5 nanobelts involves an anti-Ostwald ripening process, where the [010] orientation of V2O5 nanobelts is ascribed to the V2O5 layered structure with anisotropic bonding, which leads to rapid nucleation rate for V2O5 at [010] orientation, which is inferred from the DFT calculation. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits capacity of 6 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 2940 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 151 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 58.8 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒1.0 V. Organic materials are promising earth abundant cathode materials for SIBs but their dissolution in organic electrolyte and poor electrical conductivity limits their application. Hence polymerizing redox-active molecules on flexible conductive carbon based materials can alleviate these problems, where covalent bond between the molecules can prevent their dissolution while conductive matrix facilitates redox reactions. Liu et al. [87] have demonstrated polydopamine-FWCNTs (FWCNTs: few-walled carbon nano-tubes) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the polydopamine-FWCNTs by coating polydopamine on FWCNTs via oxidative self-polymerization of dopamine in weak alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 1c; Table S1c). They found that after the anodic polymerization process, the polydopamine-FWCNTs exhibit steady-state redox peaks at ∼2.8 V vs. Na, and this large redox potential indicates that polydopamine is a promising organic cathode material for SIB. It is bendable flexible electrode (Fig. 1d) and exhibits capacity of 54 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 10,000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼67 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 250 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles with operation voltage range 4.2‒1.3 V. Besides, Huang et al. [38] have demonstrated rGO-polyimide (rGO: reduced graphene oxide) as a flexible organic cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the rGO-polyimide by hydrothermal treatment followed by annealing (Table S1(d)). They found that the 3D rGO-polyimide comprised of polyimide particles with 100‒150 nm in size, which are uniformly placed on the surface as well as encapsulated in the interior of graphene walls, where the growth of the polyimide into the graphene is ascribed to the π-π interaction between conjugated aromatic rings of polyimide and graphene. The rGO-polyimide with polyimide particle integrated with 3D porous framework enhances ion diffusion and provides fast electron transfer from the graphene framework to polyimide particle that enhances redox reaction. The rGO-polyimide cathode was obtained by mechanical pressing of the as-prepared material from ∼2 mm to ∼30 µm thin film (Fig. 2 a), and it retains its structure and exhibits the 0.73 g cm‒3 of packing density, while the binder-free electrode shows electrical conductivity from 2.38 S cm‒1 to 2.27 S cm‒1 after 100 times bending, which indicating its high mechanical flexibility. The bendable flexible rGO-polyimide electrode exhibits high capacity of 116 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼93 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 Ma g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range 3.5‒1.5 V. Moreover, Zhang et al. [97] have demonstrated graphene-PAQS-aerogel (PAQS: poly(anthraquinonyl sufide)) as a potential flexible organic cathode material for SIB. They synthesized graphene-PAQS-aerogel using dispersion-assembly method (Table S1(e)). They found that graphene-PAQS-aerogel is composed of PAQS of 100‒200 nm in size, which are homogenously distributed on the surface of the graphene and effectively encapsulated by graphene sheets via π-π stacking interaction. The graphene-PAQS-aerogel cathode was obtained by the mechanical pressing of the as-prepared material from ∼4 mm to ∼30 µm thin film, while it retains its structure and maintains its electrical conductivity after bending test, which indicates its flexibility. The bendable flexible graphene-PAQS-aerogel electrode exhibits capacity of 72 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 1125 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 98.7 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 112.5 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range 2.8‒1.2 V. 1D nanostructured material coated with carbon integrated with flexible conductive matrix such as graphene can provide bicontinuous electron/ion pathway and it can be a promising cathode material for SIBs. Zhang et al. [93] have demonstrated Na7V4(P2O7)4(PO4)-C-graphene as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized the Na7V4(P2O7)4(PO4)–C–graphene as described in Table S1(f). They found that it is crystalline and containing 1D nanorods encapsulated by graphene sheets layer by layer, where the nanorods are rectangular with 1‒2 µm in length and 200‒300 nm in diameter. They proposed that the cathode containing carbon coating on the Na7V4(P2O7)4(PO4)-C nanorod and graphene nanosheet framework exhibits bicontinuous electron pathways (Fig. 2b), which enhance its electrochemical kinetics. It is bendable flexible electrode. It exhibits capacity of 30 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 30 C, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼82 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1 C after 200 cycles with operation voltage range from 4.1 to 2.5 V. Layered oxide Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2 is a promising cathode for SIBs whereas its poor electrical conductivity hampers its application. Integrating layered oxides with flexible conductive matrix such as graphene can enhance its electrical conductivity and electrochemical performance. Yang et al. [94] have demonstrated Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2-rGO as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. They synthesized Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2-rGO by sol–gel method followed by ultrasonic dispersion Table S1(g). They observed that Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2 particles of 300 nm in diameter are wrapped up by the rGO in layer by layer arrangement (Fig. 2c), where the π–π bonds of rGO provide strong binding with Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2 particles, which facilitate its electrical conductivity that enhances its electrochemical performance. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits capacity of ∼46 mAh g‒1 at current density of 86.3 mA g‒1, cycling stability by retaining 80 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 8.6 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒2.0 V. Mechanical properties and conductivity of the flexible matrix can be further enhanced by performing a metallic coating over it. Prussian blue@graphene oxide@Ni-cotton textile (Prussian blue@GO@Ni - cotton textile) [88] has been reported as a potential hybrid flexible cathode material for SIB. As described in Table S1(h), Prussian blue@graphene oxide@Ni-cotton textile was prepared. It is comprised of GO nanosheets connected Prussian blue cubes, which covered the Ni coated cotton textile, where Prussian blue@GO facilitates ionic/electronic conductivity, and Ni coated cotton textile affords high flexibility with high electronic conductivity, and that enhances its Na-storage performance and flexibility. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits capacity of 67 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 3600 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 69 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 600 mA g‒1 after 1800 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒2.0 V, while it powers LED at bent state (Fig. 2d), which suggests its flexibility. Polyanionic compounds are promising cathode materials for SIBs due to its open framework structure but their poor electrical conductivity limits their cycling stability. Hence, integrating it with carbon cloth can enhance its Na-storage performance and flexibility. Song et al. [89] have demonstrated Na2FeP2O7 CC (CC: carbon cloth) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. It was synthesized as described in Table S1(i). It is composed of 20‒50 nm in size of Na2FeP2O7 nanoparticles with triclinic structure, which are uniformly embedded on porous carbon cloth. It is bendable flexible electrode (Fig. 2e) and exhibits capacity of 55 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 60 C, much high cycling stability by retaining ∼62 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 10 C after 10,000 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒2.0 V. Prussian blue and its analogues are considered as promising cathode materials for SIBs due to their low temperature synthesis procedure and their rigid framework structure, but their inferior electronic conductivity and deficiencies in their framework restrict their cycling stability. Hence tailoring their morphology and integrating with flexible conductive framework can obviate this problem. Nie et al. [92] have demonstrated FeFe(CN)6 CC as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. It was prepared by solution precipitation route (Table S1(j)). It is composed of ∼200 nm in size FeFe(CN)6 nanoparticles with face-centered cubic structure, which are interconnected and homogenously distributed on the carbon cloth (Fig. 2f and g), and that enhances fast electron transport, facilitates electrolyte interaction, shortens diffusion path of Na+/e‒, eliminates binder/additives, and improves its Na-storage performance with flexibility. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits capacity of 62 mAh g‒1 at current density of 600 mA g−1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼41 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 120 mA g‒1 after 1200 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒2.0 V. Ternary oxides are promising cathode materials for SIBs but their poor cycling stability hampers their application. Therefore tailoring their morphology and integrating with flexible conductive framework can eliminate this problem. Mo et al. [96] have demonstrated NiCo2O4-CFC (CFC: carbon fiber cloth) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. It was prepared by hydrothermal treatment at 100 °C for 10 h followed by heat treatment at 400 °C for 2 h in N2 atmosphere. It possesses unique hierarchical 3D porous nanostructure, in which, polycrystalline 1D NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays (with cubic spinel phase and ∼60 nm in diameter) are uniformly grown on carbon fiber cloth, which reduces diffusion path of Na+/e‒, facilitates fast electron transport, enhances electrolyte interaction, obviates binder/additives, and improves its Na-storage performance with flexibility. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits high capacity of 363 mAh g‒1at current density of 400 mA g‒1, cycling stability by retaining 542 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 50 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles with operation voltage range 3.0‒0.01 V. 2.1.2 Flexible cathode materials without carbon matrix for SIBs Integrating cathode materials with flexible carbon matrix is a promising way to fabricate flexible cathode materials for SIBs. On the other hand, without integrating cathode materials with flexible carbon matrix that is preparing nano-structured cathode materials especially nanowire membrane is another promising way to fabricate flexible cathode materials for SIBs. Wang et al. [91] have demonstrated H2V3O8 NW membrane (NW: nano-wire) as a potential flexible cathode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(k) (Fig. 2h). It is composed of uniform orthorhombic H2V3O8 nanowires with ∼100 nm in width and several hundred µm in length, while the membrane thickness is ∼35 µm, which enhances its flexibility and Na-storage performance. After charge/discharge process, it retains almost its crystal structure, and it also retains V4+ and V5+ ions but the peaks of V4+ are strengthen due to the partial reduction of V5+, which indicates its structural stability. It is bendable flexible electrode (Fig. 2h) and exhibits capacity of 38 mAh g‒1 at current density of 500 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 53 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 100 mA g‒1 after 280 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒1.5 V. 2.1.3 High Na storage performance of flexible cathode materials for SIBs In addition to the several merits of flexible electrodes such as flexible, thin, and lightweight, they should also possess high Na storage performance, which is one of the essential criteria for the flexible electrode materials for SIBs. Several kinds of flexible cathodes such as sulfate based (Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF [86]), polymer based (polydopamine-FWCNTs [87], rGO-polyimide [38], graphene-PAQS-aerogel [97]), metal-hexacyanometalates based (FeFe(CN)6 CC[92], Prussian blue@GO@Ni-cotton textile [88]) polyanionic based (Na2FeP2O7 CC [89], Na7V4(P2O7)4(PO4)-C-graphene [93]), oxide based (V2O5-nano-belt-MWCNTs [90], NiCo2O4 CFC [96], γ-Fe2O3 CNTs [95], Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2-rGO [94]), oxides without carbon matrix (H2V3O8 NWmembrane [91]) have been reported. Oxide based NiCo2O4 CFC [96] flexible cathode exhibits high capacity of 363 mAh g‒1 at 400 mA g‒1while it retains 542 mAh g‒1 at 50 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles, and rGO - polyimide [38] exhibits high capacity of 116 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 while it retains ∼93 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles. The flexible cathodes such as polydopamine-FWCNTs [87] (54 mAh g‒1 at 10,000 mA g‒1), Na2+2 x Fe2‒ x (SO4)3 C NF [86] (∼53 mAh g‒1 at 3880 mA g‒1), Prussian blue@GO@Ni-cotton textile [88] (67 mAh g‒1 at 3600 mA g‒1), γ-Fe2O3 CNTs [95] (∼50 mAh g‒1 at 3000 mA g‒1), V2O5-nano-belt-MWCNTs [90] (61 mAh g‒1 at 2940 mA g‒1), Na2FeP2O7 CC [89] (55 mAh g‒1 at 60 mA g‒1), rGO - polyimide [38] (116 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1), and NiCo2O4 CFC [96] (363 mAh g‒1 at 400 mA g‒1) exhibit high rate capacity. The flexible cathode, Na2FeP2O7 CC [89] (active material mass loading: 1‒1.5 mg cm‒2) exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining ∼62 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 10 C after 10,000 cycles with operation voltage range 4.0‒2.0 V, while the flexible cathodes such as Prussian blue@GO@Ni-cotton textile [88] (at active material mass loading of 0.5 mg cm‒2: 69 mAh g‒1 at 600 mA g‒‒1after 1800 cycles), graphene-PAQS-aerogel [97] (at active material mass loading of ∼2.3 mg cm‒2: 98.7 mAh g‒1 at 112.5 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), and rGO - polyimide [38] (at active material mass loading of ∼2.2 mg cm‒2: ∼93 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles) exhibit high cycling stability, which are even better or well-comparable with the cycling stability of various promising non-flexible cathode materials such as Na3V2(PO4)3-F [98] (at active material mass loading of 0.96 mg cm‒2: 84 mAh g‒1 at 2C after 1000 cycles), Na0.67Ni0.1Cu0.2Mn0.7O2 [99] (∼60 mAh g‒1 at 170 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles), NaFe2PO4(SO4)2 [100] (100 mAh g‒1 at 0.1 C after 50 cycles), Na0.67Mn0.67Ni0.28Mg0.05O2 [101] (at active material mass loading of ∼4 mg cm‒2: ∼97 mAh g‒1 at 17.3 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles), Na7V3(P2O7)4 [102] (at active material mass loading of 2 mg cm‒2: ∼53 mAh g‒1 at 80 mA g‒1 after 600 cycles), Na2Fe(C2O4)F2 [103] (at active material mass loading of 6‒8 mg cm‒2: ∼63 mAh g‒1 at 10 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles), K x Na y MnFe(CN)6 [104] (107.5 mAh g‒1 at 40 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles), NaCr1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 [105] (at active material mass loading of 1.8‒2.1 mg cm‒2: 100 mAh g‒1 at 10 mA g‒1 after 35 cycles), Na3Fe2(PO4)3 [106] (∼92 mAh g‒1 at 1 C after 200 cycles), Na2FeSiO4 [107] (∼37 mAh g‒1 at 200 mA g‒1 after 20 cycles), Na0.44MnO2 [108] (at active material mass loading of 2 mg cm‒2: 105 mAh g‒1 at 60 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles), and Na4VO(PO4)2 [109] (at active material mass loading of 2 mg cm‒2: ∼50 mAh g‒1 at 78 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles). 2.2 Flexible anode materials for SIBs 2.2.1 Flexible anode materials with carbon matrix for SIBs Hybridizing the potential anode materials with carbonaceous materials such as carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, and carbon cloth is the useful strategy for the fabrication of flexible anode materials for SIBs, which can also enhance high electronic/ionic conductivity and that enhances the electrochemical properties. Table 4 depicts the working potential range, capacity, and cycling stability of recently reported various kinds of flexible anode materials for SIBs [39,110–139]. Carbon matrix such as graphene stacks can be used as a promising flexible anode material for SIB. Choe et al. [134] have demonstrated graphene stacks as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(l). It shows I defect-induced (D)/I graphenic-induced (G) ratio of ∼1.2, which indicates that the hexagonal crystal structure of the carbon attains several nanometers in size, while it depicts sharp graphite phase, suggesting a well stacking order of graphene layers. It possesses density of 1.78 g cm‒3, and this is higher than the tap density of ∼1 g cm‒3 of conventional graphite-based electrodes; it exhibits high electrical conductivity (∼1.6 × 102 S cm‒1), and mechanical properties (tensile modulus: ∼920 MPa; strength: ∼23.6 MPa), and that enhances its Na-storage performance and flexibility. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits high capacity of ∼100 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 4000 mA g−1, cycling stability by retaining ∼125 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 300 mA g−1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range 4.45‒1.0 V. Doping of non-metallic chalcogens such as S with flexible carbon matrix can enhance its Na-storage performance while retain its flexibility and that can be a promising anode material for SIB. Islam et al. [121] have demonstrated S-graphene foam as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(m). It shows I D/I G ratio of 1.28, which indicates that the S doping generates large proportion of defects and lattice distortion of the carbon. It shows crumbled morphology, and it possesses high specific surface area of 537 m2 g‒1 and average pore diameter of 3‒40 nm, while the hierarchical arrangement of meso and micropores causes it as an ultra-light material (density: 1.64 mg cm‒3) and that enhances its Na-storage performance and flexibility. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits high capacity of 168 mAh g‒1 at current density of 2000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼350 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 200 cycles with operation voltage range 3.0‒0.01 V. Besides, Deng et al. [128] have demonstrated S-graphene as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was synthesized as described in Table S1(n). It shows I D/I G ratio of 1.29, which suggests that large proportion of defects on the crystal structure of the carbon is formed by the S doping. It exhibits additional redox sites for Na+ ions reaction and stimulates huge interspacing layers after S doping, which enhances its Na-storage performance. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits capacity of 89 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 244 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 100 mA g‒1 after 300 cycles with operation voltage range 3.0‒0.01 V. Doping of non-metals such as P with flexible carbon matrix can improve its Na-storage performance and that can be a promising anode material for SIB. Lu et al. [110] have demonstrated P-doped carbon cloth as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(o). It shows I D/I G ratio of 1.09, which indicates its amorphous characteristic with defects, after P-doping eliminates the oxygen functional groups in the carbon matrix, which decreases the generation of excessive solid electrolyte interface (SEI) and that enhances its initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE). It exhibits high electronic conductivity, which facilitates its Na-storage performance. The P-doped carbon cloth (∼600 °C) exhibits higher thermal decomposition temperature than undoped carbon cloth (∼500 °C), which indicates its thermal stability. Wang et al. [130] have demonstrated N-doped carbon nano-fiber as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was synthesized as described in Table S1(p). It depicts tensile strain of 1.689% with a tensile stress of 0.875 MPa, which indicates its high mechanical stability. It shows I D/I G ratio of 1.36, which indicates the low crystallinity of carbon with disordered orientations, and that enhances its reversible Na-storage performance. It shows 564 m2 g‒1 of specific surface area with micropores (0.65 and 1.3 nm) and mesopores (2.3 nm), which increases electrolyte interaction and facilitate Na-ions diffusions. It retains its morphology, structure and elemental distribution even after 3800 cycles, revealing its high stability. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits high capacity of 154 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 15,000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 210 mAh g‒1of discharge capacity at 5000 mA g‒1 after 7000 cycles with operation voltage range 3.0‒0.01 V. [120] have demonstrated FN-graphene-paper as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(s). It is amorphous. Moreover, it shows similar discharge/charge profiles at flat and bent state at 50 mA g‒1, which suggests its high flexibility. It exhibits much high capacity of 307 mAh g‒1 at current density of 3000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 56.3 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1 after 5000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. The E-MoS2-carbon fiber is composed of MoS2 nanoflowers (size: ∼140 nm), which are densely and homogenously anchored on carbon fibers, where the interlayer spacing of MoS2 nanoflowers is increased to ≥ 1.34 nm, which is much higher than the interlayer spacing of commercial MoS2 (0.62 nm), where the MoS2 anchored on carbon fibers can facilitate the electron transfer during discharge/charge process, while the enlarged interlayer spacing can diminish the ion diffusion resistance and enhance the active surface area to electrolyte, and that enhanced its electrochemical performance. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits high capacity of 104 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 20,000 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 109 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 10,000 mA g‒1 after 3000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. Ferrous sulfide (FeS) is a promising earth abundant anode material for SIBs but its poor cycling stability limits its application. [131] have demonstrated FeS@CCC as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(y). [138] have demonstrated Ni3V2O8 CC as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. The discharge plateaus below 0.4 V are attributed to the Na intercalation process, while the Na x Sn alloy is formed after discharged to 0.01 V, which is ascribed to the Na15Sn4 alloy having (220) plane with 0.46 nm of interplanar distance (Fig. 3e); After charged to 2.0 V, stepwise dealloying is occurred, which is indicated by the existence of the four distinct potential plateaus at 0.23, 0.56, 0.69, and 0.85 V, where the Na15Sn4 alloy is dealloyed into metallic Sn having (200) plane with 0.29 nm of interplanar distance (Fig. 3e); It exhibits 905.4 and 631.2 mAh g−1 for the first discharge and charge capacities, respectively, with 70% of Coulombic efficiency (CE), where the high CE suggests that unwanted reaction between Sn and electrolyte is predominantly obviated by its integrated structure; The capacity loss in the first cycle is ascribed to the generation of SEI, which could be due to the decomposition of electrolyte and reduction of Sn; It exhibits well overlapped discharge/charge curves from 2nd to 20th cycles, which indicates its reversibility and stability. [124] have demonstrated SnS-NC-graphene-NR (NC: nano-crystals; NR: nano-ribbons) as a potential flexible anode material for SIB, which alleviates the volume change of Sn upon cycling. They examined the surface of SnS2-NC-graphene-NR after 100 cycles at 1000 mA g‒1: Its surface remains intact after 100 cycles; Ultrafine nanoparticles without particle aggregation are observed but the crystalline SnS2 transforms into amorphous phase upon cycling; The homogenous distribution of SnS2 on carbon matrix is still observed, which indicates its stability. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits high capacity of ∼260 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 10,000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 355 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1500 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. It is bendable flexible electrode and exhibits high capacity of 170 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 10,000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼296 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. In addition, Mao et al. [112] have demonstrated TiO2-Sn@C NF paper as a potential flexible anode material for SIB, which minimizes volume change of Sn upon cycling. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits much high capacity of 650 mAh g‒1 at current density of 100 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 413 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 100 mA g‒1 after 400 cycles with operation voltage range from 2.0 to 0.01 V. [129] have demonstrated CuOC NF as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared by electrospinning followed by carbonization (Table S1(ae)).
