It was prepared by electrospinning followed by carbonization (Fig. 3g; Table S1(af)). It is composed of ∼63 wt% of cubic spinel-type CuCo2O4 nano-dot (∼3 nm in size), which are uniformly distributed in N-doped C NF (diameter: ∼80 nm), where the nanostructured material with abundant defects and vacancies affords short transport length for electrons, and the uniformly embedded CuCo2O4 nano-dot enhances its utilization rate while the N-doped carbon framework not only provides conductivity and flexibility but also suppresses huge volume expansion of CuCo2O4 grains. They proposed that in the 1st discharge process, CuCo2O4 exhibits irreversible reaction (CuCo2O4 + 8 Na+ + 8e− → Cu + 2Co + 4Na2O) by the formation of metallic Cu and Co products, while the subsequent discharge process exhibits reversible reaction as follows: 2 Cu + Na2O ↔ Cu2O + 2 Na+ + 2e−; Cu2O + 2Na2O ↔ 2CuO + 4Na+ + 4e−; 3Co + 4Na2O ↔ Co3O4 + 8Na+ + 8e−. It is bendable flexible electrode (Fig. 3g) and it exhibits high capacity of 297 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 5000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 317 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. 2.2.2 Flexible anode materials without carbon matrix for SIBs Integrating anode material with flexible carbon matrix is a promising way to fabricate flexible anode materials for SIBs. On the other hand, without integrating anode materials with flexible carbon matrix that is preparing nano-structured anode materials on flexible substrate such as copper foil is another promising way to fabricate flexible anode materials for SIBs. Yuan et al. [133] have demonstrated CuONRA-Cu (NRA: nano-rod arrays) as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared by heating the alkaline treated Cu foil under vacuum atmosphere (Table S1(ag)). It comprises of monoclinic CuO nano-rod arrays on copper foil (Fig. 3h), where the nanostructured morphology not only enhances electrolyte interaction but also suppresses the volume change upon cycling. They observed the charge/discharge mechanism of CuONRA-Cu foil using XPS studies: It shows only Cu2+ before the electrochemical test, while after discharging to 0 V, the intensity of Cu2+ peak reduces whereas the Cu0 and Cu1+ emerge, which suggests the reduction of CuO to Cu2O and Cu0; After charging to 3.0 V, the Cu2+ is regenerated due to the oxidation of Cu to Cu2O and CuO, while some residual metallic Cu is still observed, which could further enhance its electronic conductivity. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits high capacity of ∼200 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 290.6 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 200 mA g‒1 after 450 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0 V. Integrating carbon coated nano-SnO x with flexible conductive copper foil can improve its cycling stability and can be a promising anode material for SIB. Bian et al. [111] have demonstrated C-SnO x -NS-Cu (NS: nano-sheets) as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was synthesized as described in Table S1(ah). It is composed of 5‒10 nm in thick carbon coated SnO x (rutile SnO2 and SnO) nanosheet on copper foil, where the hierarchical porous architecture enhances electrolyte interaction while the carbon coating not only enhances its electronic conductivity but also suppresses the strains induced by the volume change upon cycling. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits high capacity of 300 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 510 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 100 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles with operation voltage range from 2.0 to 0.01 V. Integrating carbon matrix with flexible copper foil can be a promising anode material for SIB. Liu et al. [39] have demonstrated graphene-C NF-Cu (NF: nanofiber) as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared as described in Table S1(ai). It is composed of thin, and highly exfoliated with monolayers/bilayers graphene nanoflakes, which are uniformly scrolled within the porous amorphous carbon nanofibers on copper foil, which afford large active sites and shorten ion diffusion length. It possesses high specific surface area of 303 m2 g‒1, which enhances electrolyte interaction. It shows I D/I G ratio of 1.07, which indicates its disordered structure with abundant vacancies and defects. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits high capacity of 261.1 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 10,000 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining 300.8 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 2000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from 2.5 to 0.01 V. Organic materials are promising earth abundant anode materials for SIBs but their poor stability and intrinsic electrical conductivity limit their application. However, suitable molecular design can enhance their Na-storage performance. He et al. [136] have demonstrated HsGDY (hydrogen substituted graphdiyne) as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. The hydrogen substituted carbon-rich graphdiyne film was synthesized via an in situ cross-coupling reaction of triethynylbenzene on Cu foil in pyridine. It is composed of carbon-rich polymer, where each unit is comprised of 42-C hexagons, which are connected using 6 C6H6 rings via butadiyne linkages (−CC–CC–), while it possesses large pores with H group in the pores, low atom density, and large π-conjugation system, which could afford high conductivity, and it contains C–C (sp 2), C–C (sp), C–O, and CO bonds, and it possesses low energy gap (0.75 eV), and it exhibits high electronic conductivity (1.02 × 10–3 S m–1), and it possesses plentiful of pores including macroporous and mesoporous, and it shows high surface area (668 m2 g–1), and that enhances its Na-storage performance. It exhibits much high capacity of 220 mAh g‒1at current density of 5000 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 360 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.005 V. Polymeric film can be used as a promising flexible anode material for SIB. Yuan et al. [127] have demonstrated polypyrrole film as a potential flexible anode material for SIB. It was prepared via vapor phase polymerization method (Table S1aj). It exhibits ordered structure, while it shows I D/I G ratio of 0.83, which indicates its suitable degree of order. It is composed of C, N, and O, with a small quantity of S, where the N and S can enhance its capacity and rate performance. It contains C‒C/CC, C‒N (α-carbons), ‒CH‒ (β-carbons), O‒CO, CO, C‒O/O‒C‒O, (‒NH‒), C‒N+ and CN+ bonds. They proposed charge/discharge mechanism for polypyrrole film (Fig. 3i): During discharge, Na-ions are stored along the polymer backbones and the Na-ions can form bond with oxygen atoms, and hence the ordered layered structure reduces upon discharge process; Upon charge, the Na‒O bond is destroyed and ordered layered structure of pyrrolic chains is regenerated; Nevertheless, during discharge, the d-spacing between the pyrrolic chain layers slightly increases by the Na-ions storage due to the flexibility of polymer; This suggest that polypyrrole film possesses memory effect by self-adapt to the intercalated ionic radius, and this structural change can improve its subsequent cycling stability. It is bendable flexible electrode and it exhibits capacity of 93.8 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 20 C, high cycling stability by retaining ∼130 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 10 C after 1000 cycles with operation voltage range from 3.0 to 0.01 V. 2.2.3 High Na storage performance of flexible anode materials for SIBs Flexible electrode materials can exhibit several merits such as they can alleviate the usage of binders, additives, and current collector, while they can be lightweight, thin, and flexible, those can be favorable for growing flexible electronic devices. Nevertheless, they could also afford high Na storage performance. Several kinds of flexible anodes as shown in Table 4 such as carbonaceous materials (graphene stacks), sulfur based (S-graphene foam, S-graphene), nitrogen/phosphorus/fluorine-doped (P-CC, NC-NF, NP-C-fiber-g-C3N4, P-N-graphene paper, FN-graphene-paper), Sn based (Sn-nano-dot-N-C NF, SnS2 NC-graphene-NR, graphene-foam-CNTs-SnO, TiO2-Sn@C NF paper), metallic support without carbon matrix (CuONRA - Cu foil, C-SnO x -Cu foil, graphene-CNF - Cu foil), polymer based without carbon matrix (polypyrrole) have been reported. The P-N-graphene paper [114] flexible anode exhibits high capacity of 809 mAh g‒1 at 1500 mA g‒1. The flexible anodes such as NC-NF [130] (154 mAh g‒1 at 15,000 mA g‒1), Sn-nano-dot-N-C NF [115] (450 mAh g‒1 at 10,000 mA g‒1), graphene-C NF-Cu foil [39] (261.1 mAh g‒1at 10,000 mA g‒1), SnS2 NC-graphene-NR [124] (∼260 mAh g‒1 at 10,000 mA g‒1), graphene-foam-CNTs-SnO nano-flakes [125] (170 mAh g‒1 at 10,000 mA g‒1), and NP-C-fiber-g-C3N4 [123] (64 mAh g‒1 at 10,000 mA g‒1 exhibit high rate capacity. The flexible anode, NC-NF [130] (mass: 0.64 mg cm‒2) exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 210 mAh g‒1 at 5000 mA g‒1 after 7000 cycles while the flexible anodes such as FN-graphene-paper [120] (56.3 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1after 5000 cycles), NP-C-fiber-g-C3N4 [123] (mass: ∼0.15 mg cm‒2; 110 mAh g‒1at 1000 mA g‒1 after 4000 cycles), SnS2 NC-graphene-NR [124] (mass: 0.78 mg cm‒2; 355 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1500 cycles), Sn-nano-dot-N-C NF [115] (mass: ∼1.5 mg cm‒2; 483 mAh g‒1 at 2000 mA g‒1 after 1300 cycles), CuCo2O4 nano-dot@NC NF [126] (317 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), graphene-C NF-Cu foil [39] (massactive material: ∼1.2 mg cm‒2; 300.8 mAh g‒1 at 2000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), graphene-foam-CNTs-SnO nano-flakes [125] (massactive material: 1.95 mg cm‒2; ∼296 mAh g‒1at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), and polypyrrole [127] (∼130 mAh g‒1 at 10 C after 1000 cycles) exhibit high cycling stability, which are even better or well-comparable with the cycling stability of various promising non-flexible anode materials such as Kelp-Hard Carbon [140] (massactive material: 0.8‒1.2 mg cm‒2; 205 mAh g‒1 at 200 mA g‒1 after 300 cycles), TiO2 [141] (∼145 mAh g‒1 at 50 mA g‒1 after 600 cycles), Na2/3Ni1/6Mg1/6Ti2/3O2 [142] (massactive material: 3‒4 mg cm‒2; ∼87 mAh g‒1 at 9.6 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles), Na2Ti3O7 [143] (massactive material: 2 mg cm‒2; 85 mAh g‒1 at 400 mA g‒1 after 1100 cycles), TiNb2O7 [144] (∼60 mAh g‒1 at 200 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles), Mg0.5Ti2(PO4)3 [145] (159.8 mAh g‒1 at 1000 mA g‒1 after 300 cycles), NaV3(PO4)3 [146] (140 mAh g‒1 at 100 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles), and 6.99%-Fe–TiO2 [147] (mass: 1.4‒1.8 mg cm‒2; 127.3 mAh g‒1 at 1680 mA g‒1 after 3000 cycles). 2.3 Flexible full SIBs Bendable full SIBs can be prepared by tailoring the properties of electrolyte and electrode materials. Table 5 shows the working potential range, capacity, cycling stability, lighting LED at bent state, and cycling stability at bent state of recently reported different types of flexible full SIBs [148–153]. Flexible full SIB is prepared by using NASICON-type Na3Zr2Si2PO12 hybrid solid electrolyte along with polymeric binder. Kim et al. [151] have reported potential flexible SIB contains NaFePO4 as cathode, hard carbon as anode, Na3Zr2Si2PO12 composite as ceramic based hybrid solid electrolyte, and poly(vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene) as polymeric binder. They found that the hybrid solid electrolyte is bendable and flexible (Fig. 4 a). They proposed a schematic model illustrate the three possible mechanisms of Na-ion conducting paths in hybrid solid electrolyte (Fig. 4b). One is ceramic ion hopping; The second is plasticizer transport of liquid electrolyte; The third is cross direction. They observed that the full cell exhibits rate capacity of 75.4 mAh g‒1 at 1 C, high cycling stability by retaining ∼115 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 0.2 C after 200 cycles, and cell voltage of 2.6 V. Moreover, it powers LED at bent state suggesting its high flexibility. SIB for powering flexible device is demonstrated by Fu et al. [149] and the SIB contains hydrogenated-Na2Ti3O7 on bendable Ti foil (h-Na2Ti3O7–Ti foil) as anode and Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2 as cathode. They prepared the hydrogenated-Na2Ti3O7 nanoarrays on Ti foil, anode by alkaline hydrothermal reaction followed by hydrogenation process. It is comprised of uniform nanotubes with external diameter of 25‒35 nm and length of ∼3 µm. It exhibits high electrical conductivity of 1.2 × 10‒4 S cm‒1. They observed that the full cell exhibits high capacity of ∼105 mAh g‒1 at current density of 5 C, high cycling stability by retaining discharge capacity of ∼155 mAh g‒1 after 100 cycles, and cell voltage of 2.7 V. The SIB also powers LED arrays in a flexible wrist strap, which indicates its high flexibility. Flexible SIB for powering bendable device is reported by Yang et al. [148] and the SIB contains N-doped carbon sheet (NC sheet) as anode and Na3V2(PO4)3 as cathode. They prepared the N-doped carbon sheet, anode by carbonization of okara source followed by exfoliation. They found lamellar structure with loosely packed micro-crystallites of graphitic sheets for NC sheet anode, which can facilitate the redox reaction by delivering sufficient electrons and that enhance its Na storage properties. They observed that the full cell exhibits high capacity of ∼107 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1.5 C, high cycling stability by retaining discharge capacity of ∼80 mAh g‒1 at 1.5 C after 200 cycles, and high cell voltage of 3.5 V. As depicted in Fig. 4(c), at bent state, the Na3V2(PO4)3//NC sheet full cell also powers flexible/wearable LED screen, which reveals its high flexibility. Integrating promising electrode materials with rGO can be promising flexible SIBs. Zhang et al. [152] have reported potential flexible SIB contains Na3V2(PO4)3 as cathode and Sb as anode where the electrode materials are integrated with rGO. Na3V2(PO4)3/rGO cathode is composed of 30‒50 nm of Na3V2(PO4)3 nanoparticles, which are encapsulated homogenously in the rGO scaffold while Sb/rGO anode is comprised of ∼10 nm of Sb nanoparticles, which are embedded uniformly in the rGO framework, which enhances their structural stability and that facilitates Na-ion intercalation/deintercalation process. They observed that the full cell exhibits high cycling stability by retaining discharge capacity of 400 mAh g‒1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g‒1 and cell voltage of ∼2.4 V. The fabrication of flexible Na3V2(PO4)3/rGO//Sb/rGO full cell is depicted in Fig. 4(d), and it powers LED at bent state and then the bent-free cell lights a LED after bending for 30 cycles, which discloses its high flexibility. Integrating promising electrode materials with hybrid polymeric-graphene scaffolds can be promising flexible SIBs. Li et al. [150] have reported potential flexible SIB contains VOPO4 as cathode and hard carbon as anode where the electrode materials are prepared on flexible PDMS/rGO sponge scaffold (PDMS = poly(dimethylsiloxane)). They synthesized the PDMS/rGO sponge framework as described in Table S1(ak). They observed that the full cell exhibits capacity of 103, 88, and 53 mAh g‒1 at 10, 20, and 100 mA g‒1, respectively, while it exhibits high cycling stability by retaining discharge capacity of ∼45 mAh g‒1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g‒1, and cell voltage of ∼2.6 V. They depict the schematic diagram (Fig. 4e) of the fabrication of flexible full cell; at stretched state, it exhibits 96 and 92 mAh g‒1at 20 % and 50 % strain, respectively, while it retains discharge capacity of ∼82 mAh g‒1 after 100 cycles at 10 mA g‒1 under 50 % strain (Fig. 4g), and it also powers LED at stretched state (Fig. 4f), which suggests its high flexibility. Aqueous flexible Na0.44MnO2//NaTi2(PO4)3 C SIB using 1 M Na2SO4 as electrolyte was demonstrated by Guo et al. [153], where the nano-sized carbon-coated NaTi2(PO4)3 anode was prepared by sol–gel method, while Na0.44MnO2 cathode was synthesized by solid-state method. They observed that the full cell exhibits capacity of ∼27 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 5000 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining discharge capacity of ∼36 mAh g‒1after 200 cycles at 200 mA g‒1 The SIB also powers LED at bent state, while it retains discharge capacity of ∼32 mAh g‒1 after 100 cycles at 200 mA g‒1 at different bending angles (0°, 45°, 90°, 135°, 180°, circle, and 0°), which indicates its high flexibility. 2.3.1 High Na storage performance of flexible full SIBs Flexible full SIBs can exhibit several merits such as they can alleviate the usage of binders, additives, and current collector, while they can be lightweight, thin, and flexible, which can be favorable for growing flexible electronic devices. However, they could also provide high Na storage performance. Several kinds of flexible full SIBs including hybrid solid electrolyte based, electrode materials with carbon matrix, electrode materials with metallic foil, electrode materials with polymer based scaffold such as Na3V2(PO4)3//NC sheet [148], Na2/3(Ni1/3Mn2/3)O2//h-Na2Ti3O7-Ti foil [149], PDMS/rGO sponge/VOPO4//PDMS/rGO sponge/hard carbon [150], NaFePO4 HSE//hard carbonHSE [151], and Na3V2(PO4)3/rGO//Sb/rGO [152] have been reported. The flexible full SIBs such as Na3V2(PO4)3/rGO//Sb/rGO [152] (400 mAh g‒1 at 100 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles) and NaFePO4 HSE//hard carbonHSE [151] (∼115 mAh g‒1at 0.2 C after 200 cycles) exhibit high cycling stability, which are even better or well-comparable with the cycling stability of various promising non-flexible full SIBs such as Na4Co3(PO4)2P2O7//hard carbon [154] (∼75 mAh g‒1 at 34 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles), Na3V2(PO4)2F3//hard carbon [155] (97 mAh g‒1 at 0.2 C after 120 cycles), Na2MnFe(CN)6•zH2O//hard carbon [156] (∼105 mAh g‒1at 100 mA g‒1 after 25 cycles), R-Na1.92Fe[Fe(CN)6]//hard carbon [157] (112 mAh g‒1 at 10 mA g‒1 after 50 cycles), and VOPO4//Na2Ti3O7 [158] (∼85 mAh g‒1 at 100 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles). 3 Flexible Li–S batteries Hybridizing the promising cathode materials with carbonaceous materials such as carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, and cotton textiles is the effective strategy for the fabrication of flexible cathode materials for Li–S batteries, which can enhance high electronic/ionic conductivity and that enhances the electrochemical properties. Table 6 depicts the working potential range, capacity, and cycling stability of recently reported various kinds of Li–S batteries with flexible cathode materials [57,159–216]. Table 7 shows the working potential range, capacity, cycling stability, lighting LED at bent state, and cycling stability at bent state of recently reported several types of flexible Li–S batteries [57,159–174,209–211]. Foldable Li–S battery can be fabricated by impregnation of the active materials into the super-elastic carbon-nanotube current-collector film in a checkerboard pattern. Li et al. [169] have reported flexible Li–S battery containing S (cathode) and Li (anode), which are impregnated on carbon nano-tube (CNT), where the CNTs with super-elastic characteristic serve as current collector as-well-as substrate for electrode materials. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of ∼660 mAh g‒1 at current density of 5025 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼640 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 837.5 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.5 V. Moreover, it also powers LED at bent state while it retains 754.1 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 837.5 mA g‒1 after 100 folding/unfolding cycles (Fig. 5 a), revealing its high flexibility. 3D CNTs as S host can inhibit the electrochemical corrosion while alleviate the passivation of cathode surface, and that enhance its electrochemical performance. Peng et al. [213] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery containing CNTs-S as cathode and Li as anode. The CNTs were prepared by modified floating CVD technique followed by solution-processed method, while flexible CNTs-S was obtained by melting-diffusion method. They observed that Li–S battery with 3D CNTs-S exhibits higher capacity and cycling stability than Li–S battery with 2D Al–S or 2D graphene film-S, where the 3D CNTs exhibit higher corrosion resistance than 2D Al, while 3D porous CNTs prevent the passivation of cathode surface without the use of interlayer whereas 2D Al or 2D graphene film exhibits passivation of cathode surface. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of ∼800 mAh g‒1 at current density of 836 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼574 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 836 mA g‒1 after 950 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.7 V. Besides, Ummethala et al. [216] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery containing CNTs-S as cathode and Li as anode. They prepared the CNTs by spray pyrolysis technique. The flexible CNTs-S is composed of sulfur, which is impregnated into porous CNTs, where C and S are uniformly distributed, the porous structure not only alleviates the dissolution of polysulfides but also inhibits the volume change of sulfur, and that enhances its electrochemical performance. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of 507 mAh g‒1 at current density of 5350.4 mA g‒1 and high cycling stability by retaining 877 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1672 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles in the voltage window of 2.6‒1.8 V. CNTs-graphene hybrid as S host can retard the volume change of sulfur and inhibit the dissolution of polysulfides, and that enhances its electrochemical performance. Sun et al. [214] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery containing S-CNTs-graphene as cathode and Li as anode. The flexible S-CNTs-graphene was synthesized by ultrasonication-assisted method. The S-CNTs-graphene is composed of crystalline sulfur particles, which are anchored on the CNTs-graphene hybrid, which not only inhibits the volume change of sulfur but also alleviates the polysulfides dissolution. They observed that Li–S battery with S-CNTs-graphene exhibits higher capacity and cycling stability than Li–S battery with S-CNTs. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of ∼897 mAh g‒1 at current density of 10 C, and high cycling stability by retaining 594 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1 C after 1000 cycles in the voltage window of 2.6‒1.9 V. MgO nanoparticles decorated CNTs as a sulfur host can inhibit the shuttle effect by covalent immobilization or polar interaction with lithium polysulfides, and that can enhance its electrochemical performance. Xiang et al. [210] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery containing MgO-CNTs-S as cathode and Li as anode. The MgO-CNTs were prepared by liquid phase immersion/adsorption process followed by pyrolysis of melamine foam (cheap source), while the MgO-CNTs-S was obtained by liquid phase infiltration followed by thermal treatment. The MgO-CNTs possess porous structure, and exhibit high surface area (120 m2 g−1), and it is composed of ultrafine MgO nanoparticles, which are uniformly distributed on CNTs, and it exhibits I G/I D ratio of 0.99, which suggests the existence of high degree of graphitization, and it shows small square resistance, which indicates its high electrical conductivity, and it contains C–C, C–N, and C–O/CO bonds, while the MgO-CNTs-S is composed of orthorhombic crystalline sulfur particles, which are uniformly distributed on MgO-CNTs, and that enhances its electrochemical performance. They observed that the Li–S battery with MgO-CNTs-S cathode exhibits higher capacity and cycling stability than the Li–S battery with CNTs-S cathode. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of ∼750 mAh g‒1 at current density of 3350 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 390 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 3350 mA g‒1 after 800 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.5 V. Moreover, it also powers LED at bent state, which revealing its high flexibility. Nano-channels of the mesoporous carbon can be used for sulfur host to suppress the polysulfide diffusion while flexible hybrid sulfur cathode can be prepared by integrating meso-porous carbon with CNTs. Sun et al. [174] have reported flexible Li–S battery containing C@S-CNTs as cathode and Li as anode. They found that the hybrid C@S-CNTs cathode material has aligned and laminated nanocarbon structure and the hybrid cathode is composed of sulfur located in the nano-channels of the mesoporous carbon particles called as C@S particles and the particles are attached on CNTs sheets known as C@S-CNTs sheets and finally; the hybrid cathode with a laminated structure is formed by cross-stacking the C@S-CNTs sheets using layer by layer approach. They observed that the Li–S battery exhibits high capacity of 473 mAh g‒1 at current density of 2 C, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼380 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 2 C after 1000 cycles in the voltage window of 2.6‒1.7 V. In addition, it also powers LED at bent state while it retains ∼405 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1 C after 50 cycles at bent state (Fig. 5b), which reveals its high flexibility. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with high porosity and specific surface area can afford strong chemical bondage with sulfur species, which can obviate the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfide, while flexible hybrid sulfur cathode can be prepared by integrating MOFs with CNTs. Mao et al. [160] have reported flexible Li–S battery containing S-MOFs-CNTs as cathode (MOFs: metal-organic frameworks) and Li as anode. They prepared the S-MOFs-CNTs by solid-precursor-assisted-confinement-conversion process (Table S1(al)). They found that the CNTs penetrate into the MOFs crystal and form porous-stratified structure (right side of the Fig. 5c), where CNTS framework can afford high flexibility and conductivity while the porous MOFs enable strong sulfur confinement with sulfur, which can diminish polysulfide diffusion. They observed that the size of the cavities of the MOFs influences the sulfur confinement (Fig. 5c), where S8 easily enters into the cavities of HKUST-1 and MOF-5 via their large entrance of 0.9 nm and 0.8 nm, respectively, whereas it is not accessible into the cavities of ZIF-8 through its comparatively small entrance of 0.34 nm. They determined that the cell exhibits high capacity of 449 mAh g‒1 at current density of 16,750 mA g‒1, high cycling stability by retaining ∼700 mAh g‒1of discharge capacity at 335 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles in the voltage window of 3.0‒1.5 V. Moreover, it also powers LED at bent state (Fig. 5d). In addition, they also evaluated its flexibility for 10 cycles at each bending angles including 0°, 45°, 90°, 135°, 180°, and 0° and they found that it retains ∼3.5 mAh cm‒2 of discharge capacity after 60 cycles at different bending angles disclosing its high flexibility. Integrating catholyte (Li2S6) with CNTs can be used as flexible cathode for Li–S battery, which not only provides flexibility but also affords conductivity and that can diminish polysulfide dissolution. Kim et al. [173] have demonstrated Li–S battery containing Li2S6-CNTs as cathode and Li as anode. Li2S6-CNTs were synthesized as described in Table S1(am). The Li2S6-CNTs cathode is composed of Li2S6, which is anchored on CNTs film, which not only affords flexibility but also suppresses polysulfide dissolution. They found that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 318 mAh g‒1 at current density of 3350 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼525 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 837.5 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles in the voltage window of 2.6‒1.7 V. In addition, it also powers LED at bent state while it retains ∼1050 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 167.5 mA g‒1 after 80 cycles at unfolded/folded state (Fig. 5e), which reveals its high flexibility. Bucky paper can afford conductivity and flexibility and therefore, integrating bucky paper with sulfur can suppress the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfide and it also retains its flexibility. Chung et al. [167] have fabricated Li–S battery containing buc paper-S-buc paper (buc paper: bucky paper) as cathode and Li as anode. They have prepared the cathode using fibrous bucky paper, which was sp 2 hybridized carbon skeleton comprised of about 20 nm in width CNTs strongly bound to > 50 µm in length carbon nanofiber framework. They have synthesized the buc paper-S-buc paper cathode by coating the sulfur active material fillings on bucky paper by tape-casting method, subsequently another bucky paper was used to cover it, which can diminish the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides and it also retains its flexibility. They observed that the cell provide high capacity of ∼900 mAh g‒1 at current density of 0.5 C, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼850 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 100 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.8 V. Moreover, at fold state, it also lights LED (inset of Fig. 5f) while it retains ∼850 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 100 cycles at bent state (Fig. 5f), which indicates its high flexibility. Porous carbon can be used for sulfur host to diminish the polysulfide diffusion while it can also afford flexibility. Wu et al. [162] have reported Li–S battery containing porous C–S as cathode and Li as anode. They constructed the cathode consists of 3D graphene based porous carbon with hierarchical architecture for sulfur encapsulation without the use of polymer binder and carbon black additives, where the 3D frame work enhance Li-ion/electron transfer and it affords huge number of micropores for confinement of sulfur and it obviates the Li-polysulfide dissolution into the electrolyte. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 502 mAh g‒1 at current density of 3350 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 647 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1675 mA g‒1 after 300 cycles in the voltage window of 3.0‒1.0 V. In addition, at fold state, it also powers LED while it retains 679 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 10 cycles at 837.5 mA g‒1 followed by 10 cycles at 1675 mA g‒1 at bent state (Fig. 6 a), which reveals its high flexibility. Carbon-nano-fibers matrix can afford high flexibility while their electrospinning synthesis process is a versatile technology. Therefore integrating active materials with carbon-nano-fibers can not only provide flexibility but also improve electronic conductivity and that can diminish the polysulfide dissolution. Yu et al. [165] have fabricated Li–S battery containing Li2S-NCNF as cathode (CNF: carbon nanofiber) and Li as anode. They have synthesized the Li2S-NCNF cathode by coupling the electro-spinning technique and carbothermal reduction chemistry of Li2SO4, which is relatively cheap synthesis process. The Li2S-NCNF cathode is comprised of Li2S nano-particles of < 10 nm, which is uniformly dispersed in the bendable interwoven framework of 3D interconnected N-doped carbon nanofibers, which enhances structural stability and reaction kinetics for electrochemical reactions. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 460 mAh g‒1 at current density of 2332 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼480 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1166 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.7 V. They found that after 200 cycles, the Li2S-NCNF cathode exhibits high structural stability by retaining structural integrity, size, shape, and elemental distribution as shown in Fig. 6(b). In addition, at fold state, the cell also lights LED revealing its high flexibility. Integrating Li2S with sulfur can suppress the polysulfide dissolution. Peng et al. [215] have fabricated Li–S battery containing S Li2S as cathode and Li as anode. By mimicking fibrinolysis, a biological self-healing process, they designed a healing agent, polysulfide, for the stable operation of sulfur microparticle cathode. They observed that the Li–S battery show high capacity of ∼640 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1500 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼700 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1500 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles in the voltage window of 3.2‒1.7 V. Besides, integrating Li2S with graphene can not only provide flexibility but also afford electronic conductivity and that can suppress the polysulfide dissolution. He et al. [161] have fabricated Li–S battery containing Li2S-graphene as cathode and Li as anode. They prepared Li2S-graphene cathode by chemical vapor deposition followed by facile infiltration method (Table S1(an)). They found that the 3D hierarchical Li2S-graphene is composed of graphene skeleton, which is uniformly covered by crystalline Li2S nano-particles of < 100 nm in size, and it is binder-free and free-standing cathode, which obviates metallic current collectors, and it possesses high surface area and porosity. They proposed an optimized configuration for Li2S-graphene cathode (Fig. 6c), where the interacting graphene sheets have been misaligned with semi part of the carbon atoms in the lattice of graphene, which overlaps in a plane view, and as a result of this closely-packed microstructure of Li2S-graphene cathode, which exhibits high capacity while it obviates the Li-polysulfide dissolution into the electrolyte. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 598.6 mAh g‒1 at current density of 4664 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼750 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 233.2 mA g‒1 after 300 cycles in the voltage window of 3.0‒1.5 V. In addition, at fold state, it also powers LED, which reveals its high flexibility. Integrating porous graphene with sulfur nanoparticles can not only inhibit the volume change of S upon cycling but also afford electronic conductivity and that can suppress the polysulfide dissolution. Cao et al. [209] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery with rGO-S as cathode, and Li as anode. They prepared rGO-S by synchronously reducing and assembling graphene oxide sheets with sulfur nanoparticles on a Zn metal surface. The rGO-S is composed of sulfur nanoparticles, which are uniformly anchored on the rGO sheet, and it possesses thin layered porous structure with huge number of wrinkles, which could trap the dissolved polysulfides and inhibit the volume change of S nanoparticles upon cycling, and the rGO-S exhibits high surface area of 635 m2 g−1, and it possesses high mechanical strength (tensile strength: 68 MPa; Young's modulus: 965 MPa; tensile strain: ∼7.3%), while it almost retains its resistance after 500 bending cycles, which indicates its high flexibility, and it contains C‒S and S‒O bonds, which could enhance the cycling stability by inhibiting the deterioration of active materials (S), and that enhances its electrochemical performance. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of ∼1000 mAh g‒1 at current density of 2 C, and high cycling stability by retaining 681 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1 C after 500 cycles in the voltage window of 2.6‒1.7 V. In addition, at fold state, it also lights LED, while at bent state, it retains ∼1100 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 25 cycles (25–50 cycles) at 0.1 C, revealing its high flexibility. Graphene can be used for strong confinement of sulfur while cheap stainless steel fibers can be used as support/current collector for the sulfur composite fabrication by simple capillary action. Liu et al. [163] have demonstrated flexible Li–S battery (Fig. 6d) with rGO-S as cathode, stainless steel (SS) fiber as current collector/substrate and Li as anode. They prepared rGO-S on SS as follows: At first, graphene oxide was prepared by modified Hummers method; Then, rGO-S composite was prepared by hydrothermal method; Finally, fibrous cathode, rGO-S on SS was prepared by capillary action process (Fig. 6d), where stainless steel fiber metal yarn was immersed in rGO-S composite suspension and dried for 20‒30 times. They found that the crystalline orthorhombic sulfur nano-particles of 2‒30 nm in diameter are uniformly scattered on multi-layer stack-like graphene. They further inferred less intense S‒S bonds from the Raman spectra and ‒S‒O‒ bond (due to oxidation in air) were observed from XPS spectra, which suggest the strongly confinement of S with rGO, and that can obviate the Li-polysulfide dissolution into the electrolyte and that enhances its stability. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 589.5 mAh g‒1 at current density of 3350 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 762.5 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 167.5 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.5 V. In addition, at bent state, it also lights LED revealing its high flexibility. Graphene based fibrous material can not only provide flexibility but also afford strong confinement with sulfur, which can suppress the polysulfide diffusion. Chong et al. [164] have fabricated Li–S battery containing rGO-CNTs-S fiber as cathode and Li as anode. They synthesized the rGO-CNTs-S fiber by one-step wet-spinning method. It is fibrous and ultra-light in weight of only 0.028 to 0.13 mg cm‒1, which not only affords flexibility but also suppresses the polysulfide diffusion. They observed that the Li–S battery show high capacity of 313 mAh g‒1 at current density of 837.5 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼410 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 167.5 mA g‒1 after 100 cycles in the voltage range of 2.8‒1.5 V. Moreover, at fold state, it also lights LED while, at bent state, its power intensity drops by ∼70 µW and it exhibits 147 µW after 30 cycles of bending but at unbent state, it retains its original power intensity of 217 µW (Fig. 6e), which discloses its high flexibility. Integrating poly(dimethyl siloxane) with graphene can not only provide flexibility but also afford strong confinement with sulfur, which can obviate the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfide. Zhou et al. [171] have demonstrated Li–S battery containing S-PDMS-graphene-foam (PDMS: poly(dimethyl siloxane)) as cathode and Li as anode. They prepared the S-PDMS-graphene-foam as described in Table S1(ao). S-PDMS-graphene-foam has porous structure and it contains crystalline graphene and orthorhombic sulfur, which not only provides flexibility but also suppresses the polysulfide diffusion. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of ∼575 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 6000 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 448 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1500 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles in the voltage range of 2.8‒1.5 V. Moreover, at bent state, it powers LED and the S-PDMS-graphene-foam electrode retains its high electrical conductivity of ∼125 S m‒1 even after 22,000 bending cycles (Fig. 6f) but the electrode surface remains intact, which shows its high flexibility. Quinonoid imine can be used as anchoring sites to trap polysulfides, and that alleviates the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Chen et al. [212] have demonstrated Li–S battery containing NPGO-S (NPGO:GO is coated by N, P-containing polymer) as cathode and Li as anode. They synthesized the NPGO by in situ co-polymerization of aniline with phytic acid on graphene oxide in aqueous dispersion for 24 h at 0 °C, while NPGO-S was prepared by melting-diffusion method. They observed based on density functional theory that the binding energy of polysulfides (Li2S8) on quinonoid imine (protonated state: − 1.61 eV/deprotonated state: − 1.83 eV) is larger than the binding energy of Li2S8 on graphene (− 1.16 eV). The NPGO-S is flexible electrode, while the NPGO is composed of N, P-containing polymer with quinonoid imine functionalities (− NH+  = / − N = ), which is coated on graphene oxide, and it exhibits coral-like morphology, and it contains P − O, − NH+ = , − NH − , and − NH2 +  − , and it exhibits high surface area (148 m2 g−1), and that enhanced its electrochemical properties. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of ∼1320 mAh g‒1 at current density of 335 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼750 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1675 mA g‒1 after 200 cycles in the voltage range of 2.8‒1.7 V, while it exhibits very little shuttle current of 2.60 × 10−4 mA cm−2. Integrating nano-sulfur, graphene, and poly(3,4-ethylene-dioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) can not only inhibit the dissolution of polysulfides but also prevent the volume change of sulfur. Xiao et al. [211] have demonstrated Li–S battery containing S-GP as cathode and Li as anode, where S-GP refers S cathode integrated with nanosulfur, graphene, and poly(3,4-ethylene-dioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS). The S-GP was prepared by vacuum filtration. The S-GP is composed of nanosulfur, which is sandwiched between graphene and PEDOT:PSS, while C, O, and S are uniformly distributed, where the homogenous distribution of nanosulfur could improve the sulfur utilization, while the sandwiched structure enhances ion/electron transportation, and that can not only prevent the dissolution of polysulfides but also alleviate the volume change of sulfur, and it contains C–S, SO, CC and C–C, and that enhanced its electrochemical properties. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 701 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 6700 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 806 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1675 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles in the voltage range of 3‒1.5 V. In addition, at fold state, it powers LED while it retains 3.08 mAh cm‒2 after 80 cycles at bent state (180°), revealing its high flexibility. TiO2 can be used for sulfur host to suppress the polysulfide diffusion while flexible hybrid sulfur cathode can be prepared by integrating TiO2 with carbon matrix. Song et al. [172] have fabricated Li–S battery containing S–TiO2-graphene-N-porous-C NF (NF: nano-fiber) as cathode and Li as anode. They synthesized the S–TiO2-graphene-N-porous-C NF as described in Table S1(ap) (Fig. 7 a). They found that S-TiO2-graphene-N-porous-C NF contains rutile phase TiO2 nanoparticles of 5 nm in size with a polycrystalline structure, while sulfur and TiO2 nanoparticles are evenly impregnated into the porous carbon nano-fiber frame work, which not only afford flexibility but also suppress the polysulfide diffusion. They observed that the Li–S battery shows high capacity of 668 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 8375 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 618 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1675 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles in the voltage range of 2.6‒1.7 V. Moreover, at bent state, it lights LED, disclosing its high flexibility. Designing of suitable separator can effectively prevent the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. The cathode integrated with separator that is fabrication of cathode on separator can facilitate the electron transport, while alleviates the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Zhou et al. [170] have demonstrated Li–S battery (Fig. 7b) containing S-graphene cathode integrated with polypropylene separator (S-graphene@PP separator) and Li anode. They synthesized S-graphene@PP separator as described in Table S1(aq). They found that the Li–S battery containing S-graphene cathode integrated with polypropylene separator exhibits higher electrochemical performance than the Li–S battery containing S-graphene cathode not-integrated with polypropylene separator because the cathode integrated with separator serves as an effective barrier, which mitigates the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides, and that could extend its cycling stability, while the design also afford good adhesion between the graphene membrane and sulfur, which diminishes the polarization and decreases the interfacial contact resistance of the battery with good rate capability. They observed that the Li–S battery with cathode integrated with separator exhibits high capacity of 512 mAh g‒1 at much high current density of 12,000 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 522 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 3000 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles in the voltage range of 2.8‒1.5 V. In addition, at fold state, it powers LED while it retains 722 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 750 mA g‒1 after 30 cycles at bent state revealing its high flexibility. Coating suitable polymeric materials on separator can interact with polysulfides, which hamper the dissolution of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Abbas et al. [168] have fabricated Li–S battery (Fig. 7c) containing S-graphene as cathode, Li as anode, and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) coated celgard as separator. They prepared the PEDOT:PSS-separator by coating the PEDOT:PSS on celgard using spray-coating method. They found that the Li–S battery with PEDOT:PSS coated celgard-separator exhibits higher electrochemical performance than the Li–S battery with pristine-separator because the PEDOT:PSS coated separator not only enhances the conductivity but also affords bifunctional effect, which prevents the dissolution of polysulfides and suppresses the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides between the cathode and anode. The bifunctional effect of PEDOT:PSS coated separator in Li–S battery alleviates the dissolution of polysulfides on cathode, where PEDOT delivers chemical interaction for insoluble Li-polysulfides such as Li2S and Li2S2 while on the other hand, PSS functions as electrostatic shield by mutual Coulombic repulsion for the soluble Li-polysulfides (Fig. 7c). In addition, the PEDOT:PSS coated separator exhibits hydrophilic surface rather than hydrophobic, which enhances the electrolyte interaction thereby facilitate electrochemical activity. They observed that the Li–S battery with PEDOT:PSS-separator exhibits high capacity of 751 mAh g‒1 at high current density of 3350 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 626 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 419 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles in the voltage range of 2.8‒1.5 V. In addition, at fold state, it powers LED, which reveals its high flexibility. Designing of suitable interlayer can trap the polysulfides from dissolution and mitigate the shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Gao et al. [159] have fabricated Li–S battery containing activated cotton textile-S-rGO as cathode, Li as anode, and KOH-activated cotton textile as interlayer (Fig. 8 a). They synthesized activated cotton textile-S-rGO as described in Table S1(ar). The rGO in activated cotton textile-S-rGO enhances the conductivity of the composite cathode, which facilitates the fast electron transfer, while a KOH-activated cotton textile is used as interlayer between separator and cathode, which prevents the dissolution of polysulfides. They found that the Li–S battery with KOH-activated cotton textile as interlayer exhibits higher electrochemical performance than the Li–S battery without interlayer because of the synergetic effect of the interlayer and composite cathode (Fig. 8a), which not only enhances the conductivity but also traps the polysulfides from dissolution and prevents the shuttle effect of polysulfides between cathode and anode. They observed that the cell with interlayer provides high capacity of ∼1000 mAh g‒1 at current density of 2.4 mA cm‒2, and high cycling stability by retaining ∼1000 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 200 cycles at 0.3, 0.6, 1.2, 1.5, 2.4, and 1.2 mA cm‒2 in the voltage window of 3.0‒1.5 V. Moreover, at fold state, it also powers LED and it retains ∼475 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1.2 mA cm‒2 after 25 cycles at normal state followed by 25 cycles at bent state, which shows its high flexibility. Besides, Fan et al. [166] have fabricated Li–S battery (Fig. 8b) containing rGO-cellulose fiber paper-S (reduced graphene oxide coated cellulose fiber paper-S) as cathode, Li as anode, and TiO2 NCN-porous-C (TiO2 nanocrystal embedded in N doped porous carbon) as interlayer. They prepared the TiO2 NCN-porous-C interlayer by electrostatic spinning followed by carbonization. They synthesized the rGO-cellulose fiber paper-S composite cathode as described in Table S1(as). They observed that the anatase phase TiO2 nanocrystals of 5‒10 nm in size are incorporated in porous disordered carbon, where the ultrafine TiO2 nanocrystals enhance active sites for polysulfides adsorption/deposition while the N-doping in TiO2 NCN-porous-C interlayer facilitates redox of entrapped polysulfides. As a result, TiO2 NCN-porous-C is used as interlayer between separator and cathode, which hinders the dissolution of polysulfides, while the rGO in rGO-cellulose fiber paper-S enhances the conductivity of the composite cathode, which facilitates the fast electron transfer. They found that the Li–S battery with TiO2 NCN-porous-C as interlayer exhibits higher electrochemical performance than the Li–S battery without interlayer because of the synergetic effect of the interlayer and composite cathode (Fig. 8b), which increases the conductivity and prevents the dissolution of polysulfides. They observed that the cell with interlayer exhibits high capacity of 732.6 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1675 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 670 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 300 cycles at 1675 mA g‒1 in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.7 V. In addition, at bent state, it also powers LED, which reveals its high flexibility. Designing of suitable electrolyte is also one of the important factors to prevent the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Liu et al. [57] have fabricated Li–S battery containing S cathode, Li anode, and pentaerythritol tetraacrylate (PETEA) based gel polymer electrolyte, where the electrolyte possesses considerably high ionic conductivity of 1.13 × 10‒2 S cm‒1. They synthesized the PETEA-based gel polymer electrolyte in a sealed container by in-situ gelation of a precursor solution (Table S1(at)). They found that the Li–S battery with PETEA-based gel polymer electrolyte exhibits higher electrochemical performance than the Li–S battery with liquid electrolyte (Fig. 8c) because the gel polymer electrolyte obviates the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides, which can be ascribed to the generation of stable protective layer on the surface of the sulfur cathode caused by the gel polymer electrolyte while on the other hand, the polysulfides are strongly immobilized by the PETEA-based gel polymer electrolyte. They further observed that the formation of integrated structure on sulfur cathode retards the volume change upon charge/discharge process while huge dendrites growth on the surface of sulfur cathode and featherlike growth on the surface of separator are substantially prevented in the PETEA-based gel polymer electrolyte, which clearly alleviate the dissolution of polysulfides in Li–S battery. They observed that the cell exhibits high capacity of 601.2 mAh g‒1 at current density of 1675 mA g‒1, and high cycling stability by retaining 529.7 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity after 400 cycles at 837.5 mA g‒1 in the voltage window of 2.8‒1.7 V. In addition, at fold state, it also lights LED while it retains 803.2 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 167.5 mA g‒1 after 45 cycles at bent state, disclosing its high flexibility. 3.1 High performance flexible Li–S batteries In addition to the various merits of flexible electrodes such as flexible, thin, and lightweight, they could also afford high performance by preventing the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. Various types of flexible Li–S batteries as shown in Table 7 including electrode materials with carbon matrix, electrode materials with polymer based separator, electrode materials with interlayer, electrode materials with polymer-gel based electrolyte such as activated cotton textile-InLy / -activated cotton textile-S-rGO//Li, S-MOFs-CNTs//Li, Li2S-graphene//Li, pC-S//Li, rGO-S//Li, rGOCNTs-S fiber//Li, Li2S-NCNF//Li, TiO2 NCNpC-InLy / -rGO-cellulose fiber paper-Sf//Li, S-gel-PETEAg//Li, buc paper-S-buc paper//Li, S-grapheneh//Li, CNTs-Si//Li, S-graphene@PP separatork//Li, S-PDMS-graphene-foam//Li, S-TiO2-graphene-NpC NF//Li, Li2S6 CNTs//Li, and C@S-CNTs//Li have been reported. The flexible Li–S batteries such as S-grapheneh//Li [168] (at 0.9‒1.1 mg cm‒2 of S loading: 626 mAh g‒1 at 419 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), S-PDMS-graphene-foam//Li [171] (at 10.1 mg cm‒2 of S loading: 448 mAh g‒1 at 1500 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles), C@S-CNTs//Li [174] (at 20 mg cm‒2 of S loading: ∼720 mAh g‒1 at 0.1 C after 50 cycles; at 1 mg cm‒2 of S loading: ∼380 mAh g‒1 at 2C after 1000 cycles), S-TiO2-graphene-NpC NF//Li [172] (at ∼1.2 mg cm‒2 of S loading: 618 mAh g‒1 at 1675 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles), and Li2S6 CNTs//Li [173] (∼525 mAh g‒1 at 837.5 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles) exhibit high cycling stability, which are even better or well-comparable with the cycling stability of various promising non-flexible Li–S batteries such as TiO2/S//Li [62] (∼406 mAh g‒1 at 0.1 C after 100 cycles), Ti6O11/S//Li [62] (∼634 mAh g‒1 at 0.1 C after 100 cycles), Ti4O7/S//Li [62] (604 mAh g‒1at 0.5 C after 250 cycles), Ti4O7/S//Li [64] (595 mAh g‒1 at 3350 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles), δ-MnO2/S//Li [65] (at 1.5 mg cm‒2 of S loading: 480 mAh g‒1 at 3350 mA g‒1 after 800 cycles), FeS2//Li [63] (∼700 mAh g‒1at 0.5 mA cm‒2 after 200 cycles), and Co9S8/S//Li [66] (at 1.5 mg cm‒2 of S loading: 643 mAh g‒1 at 3350 mA g‒1 after 400 cycles). 4 Summary and perspectives The emerging flexible electronic devices can provide high portability in wide range of application, which highly demand for the development of flexible batteries. In order to achieve the thin and flexible requirements of devices, developments of several flexible and thin electrode materials for batteries are necessary. However, the existing state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries are gradually reaching their limitation in terms of cost and energy density. Hence, flexible SIBs with abundance Na resources and Li–S batteries with high energy density could be the alternative for the Li-ion batteries in future. On one hand, SIBs are considered much attention due to the abundance resources of Na in earth's crust (> 2%) and ocean (infinite). On the other hand, Li–S batteries with S as abundance, non-toxic source have been considered much attractive because it afford high energy density of 2600 Wh kg‒1, while the energy density of Li–S batteries is ∼5 times higher than that of LIBs at a comparably lower cost. The recent advances in the development of flexible electrode materials with metallic matrix and carbonaceous matrix such as carbon nano-tubes, carbon nano-fiber, graphene, carbon cloth, carbon fiber cloth, and cotton textiles for flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries have been reviewed. Certainly, different matrixes for active materials possess their own merits and shortcomings: (i) Metallic matrix can afford flexibility whereas their rigidity and heavy weight could limit their practical application in flexible electronics, but high Na storage performance can be achieved by using metallic matrix; Using Cu foil as substrate, graphene-C NF-Cu fl anode [39] for SIB exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 300.8 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 2000 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles; (ii) Carbon matrix such as carbon cloth and graphene can provide high flexibility whereas their cost could limit their practical application in industrial-scale for flexible electronics but high performance SIBs/Li–S batteries can be obtained by using graphene/carbon cloth matrix; Using graphene as substrate, SnS2-NC-graphene-NR anode [124] for SIB exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 355 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1000 mA g‒1 after 1500 cycles; Using carbon cloth as substrate, Na2FeP2O7 CC [89], an earth-abundant Fe-based cathode for SIB exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining ∼62 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 10 C after 10,000 cycles; Using graphene as substrate, S-PDMS-graphene-foam//Li [171] Li–S battery exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 448 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1500 mA g‒1 after 1000 cycles; (iii) Carbon-nano-fibers matrix can provide high flexibility and their electrospinning synthesis process is a versatile technology. Moreover, high performance SIBs/Li–S batteries can also be achieved using carbon-nano-fibers matrix; Using carbon-nano-fibers as substrate, NC-NF [130] anode for SIB exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 210 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 5000 mA g‒1 after 7000 cycles; Using carbon-nano-fibers as substrate, S–TiO2-graphene-NpC NF//Li [172] Li–S battery exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 618 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 1675 mA g‒1 after 500 cycles; Using carbon-nano-fibers as substrate, S1‒ x Se x @pCNF//Li [178] Li–S battery exhibits significantly high cycling stability by retaining 527 mAh g‒1 of discharge capacity at 5000 mA g‒1 after 2000 cycles. Even-though, it is still developing stage for flexible SIBs/Li–S batteries to afford superior performance in practical applications, and the essential factors governing the performance of flexible SIBs/Li–S batteries should be considered in future research: 1. Recently, considerable efforts have been done to fabricate various kinds of high performance flexible electrode materials for SIBs/Li–S batteries but the high performance electrodes are very limited due to their inferior cycling stability and restricted specific capacity. Therefore, additional progresses are indeed necessary by tailoring the flexible conductive matrix and content of active material with its utilization ratio of the flexible electrodes to achieve high energy density for the whole battery, but considering the influence of the mechanical flexibility with respect to the content of the active material is also important. 2. The development of simple, rapid, versatile, and controllable fabrication methods is essentially needed to realize huge-scale and cost-effective production of flexible electrodes and batteries. Future efforts can be performed on industrial viable techniques such as advanced printing technologies [83]. 3. Design of flexible prototype batteries should be made with additional qualities like biocompatibility, implantability, stretchability, wearability, and transparency, which could be compatible in several applications such as artificial skins, biosensors, implantable devices, rolled-up displays, touch screens. 4. A flexible material could be bent at particular bending radii [74] but standard methodology to precisely measure the flexibility is not yet established. Hence, additional efforts are needed to find a standardized methodology to measure flexibility of flexible electrodes with certain factors such as variation of electrochemical/electrical properties in terms of bending radii or bending cycles. 5. The environmental and safety problems of flexible SIBs/Li–S batteries should be considered for practical applications. Hence, additional efforts are needed to fabricate safe/environmental compatible battery components including electrolytes, and electrodes. Therefore, it is anticipated that commercial successful flexible SIBs/Li–S batteries at the industrial level can arrive in the near future after obviate the current obstacles. Giebeler Energy Storage Mater. 10 2018 206 215 Mohammed-Ibrahim Jamesh obtained dual Ph.D. from the Department of Physics and Material Science, City University of Hong Kong and School of Physics, The University of Sydney, in 2014. He is currently carrying-out research at Central electrochemical research institute (CECRI), CSIR, India. His research interface with material science and biological science, which include advanced electrochemical energy storage and conversion technologies, and corrosion of biodegradable magnesium.

coredata.dc:description: Flexible energy storage devices are essential for emerging flexible electronics. The existing state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries are slowly reaching their limitation in terms of cost and energy density. Hence, flexible Na-ion batteries (SIBs) with abundance Na resources and Li–S batteries with high energy density become the alternative for the Li-ion batteries in future. This review summarizes the recent advances in the development of flexible electrode materials for SIBs with metallic matrix and carbonaceous matrix such as carbon nano-tubes, carbon nano-fiber, graphene, carbon cloth, carbon fiber cloth, and cotton textiles. Then, the potential prototype flexible full SIBs are discussed. Further, the recent progress in the development of flexible electrode materials for Li–S batteries based on carbon nano-fiber, carbon nano-tubes, graphene, and cotton textiles is reviewed. Moreover, the design strategies of suitable interlayer, separator, electrolyte, and electrodes to prevent the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfides in flexible Li–S batteries are provided. Finally some prospective investigation trends towards future research of flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries are also proposed and discussed. The scientific and engineering knowledge gained on flexible SIBs and Li–S batteries provides conceivable development for practical application in near future.
